page.title: 07SHINTY IN LOCHALSH
page.content: Shinty (or iomain camanachd as it is known in Gaelic) has been in the culture of the Celts for a long time.In former days local woodlands would supply camans which varied in size style and quality.A ball was made from all kinds of material.Driftwood probably provided Camans while corks from fishermens nets served as balls. Our present balls are cork based with a leather cover and the camans made from ash.The playing area for boys is not more than 91m-46m and goals 2.58m high-3.66m wide. The game starts with a throw up,with crossed camans in the air and has a referee and two goal judges. A full game consists of twelve players but our school takes part only in six-a-side games.Dornie School has won the Primary Schools Cup for the last two years.
